problem.display_name: Electric potential: a property of what

text.p: A charge [mathjaxinline]q[/mathjaxinline] is at a location [mathjaxinline]\vec{r}_{\rm f}[/mathjaxinline] in an electric field [mathjaxinline]E(\vec{r}_{\rm f})[/mathjaxinline]. Which of the following statements is (are) true?

choice.text: a) electric potential is a property of the electric field [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline]
b) electric potential is a property of the charge [mathjaxinline]q[/mathjaxinline].
c) electric potential is the property of an electric charge [mathjaxinline]q[/mathjaxinline] in an electric field [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}(\vec{r}_{\rm f})[/mathjaxinline]
d) electric potential may change when a charge moves in an electric field.

solution.font: a) electric potential is a property of electric field. The electric field strength is the negative gradient of the electric potential [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}(\vec{r}_{\rm f}) = - \nabla V(\vec{r}_{\rm f})[/mathjaxinline] b) As usual, you assume the charge [mathjaxinline]q[/mathjaxinline] is not so large that it affects the distribution of source charges giving rise to the electric field [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline]. Then the electric potential has nothing to do with the charge placed in the field. The electric potential [mathjaxinline]V(\vec{r}_{\rm f})[/mathjaxinline] is a property only of the electric field. c) False for the same reason that b) is false. d) False. Moving the charge [mathjaxinline]q[/mathjaxinline] around in a field [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline] does not change [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}(\vec{r}_{\rm f})[/mathjaxinline] and so it does not change [mathjaxinline]-\int _ A^ B \vec{E}(\vec{r}_{\rm f}) \cdot d\vec{\ell } = V(\vec{r}_{\rm B} ) - V(\vec{r}_{\rm A})[/mathjaxinline]
